intro: Epaltes tatei, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and ragweed, and is characterized by its bright orange to red composite flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer and early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Epaltes tatei is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine.
